overview.title: Overview
overview.description: InkLink is a platform for collaborative storytelling, enabling writers to extend, remix, and contribute to shared narratives. Our goal was to create an experience that is social, playful, and editorial, supporting participation without overwhelming users. This project was team-based, with contributions across design, illustration, and front-end development.

research.title: Research & Ideation
research.description: We began by understanding the audience: competitive analysis of existing writing tools, surveys with writers and creative communities, and workshop sessions to identify needs and pain points. Key insight: Writers wanted inspiration and connectivity, not just a blank canvas. Lo‑fi sketches and user journeys in Figma mapped early flows for story creation, contribution, and exploration.

lofi.title: Lo‑Fi Exploration & Early Concepts
lofi.description: Wireframed navigation, story discovery, and contribution screens. Tested interaction logic with peers. Feedback highlighted confusion around entry points and contribution actions. Iteration: Simplified the flow so exploration is the default state and designed progressive reveal interactions to guide users.

iterations.title: Iterations & Refinements
iterations.description: Story Entry Clarity: Highlighted CTAs for joining stories with motion and scale. Hover Previews / Spatial Layout: Removed containers; visuals float in whitespace for editorial impact. Motion Refinement: Retuned animations for snappy, ease-in/ease-out pop-out interactions.

solution.title: Final Solution
solution.description: Editorial layout: asymmetry, whitespace, and modular sections. Interactive hover previews: images/videos float freely, with snappy motion. Team visuals: give personality and emphasize collaboration. Built in Framer, using Figma and Illustrator assets.

outcomes.title: Impact & Lessons Learned
outcomes.description: Successfully communicates collaborative creativity. Balances expressive visuals with usability. Shows strong team collaboration and iterative design process. Lessons Learned: Motion supports storytelling, not just decoration. Negative space and editorial layout enhance readability. Iterations from lo-fi to high-fi are essential for clarity and polish.
